section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: A hands-on introduction to the fundamental building blocks of Python programming. Students will learn how to store, manipulate, and understand different kinds of data through practical exercises and real-world examples.
learning_objectives: Define variables to store different data types.
Apply type conversion functions to change data from one type to another.
Perform basic arithmetic and string operations using variables.
Identify the data type of any given value or variable.
Write programs that accept user input and display formatted output.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create variables following Python naming conventions and assign values of basic data types.
key_topics: Variable assignment using the equals sign (=)
Python naming rules (case-sensitive, no spaces, cannot start with a number)
Choosing meaningful variable names
The print() function to display variable values
Reassigning variables with new values

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables to store your name, age, and favorite color. Print each variable to the console.
Create a variable called 'score' and set it to 10. Print it. Then reassign it to 15 and print it again.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to perform mathematical operations with numeric data types and manipulate string data.
key_topics: Integer (int) and floating-point (float) data types
Basic arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, **)
String creation using single, double, and triple quotes
String concatenation with the plus (+) operator
String repetition with the asterisk (*) operator

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create two variables holding numbers. Perform addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division on them, printing each result.
Create a variable with your first name and another with your last name. Concatenate them into a full name variable and print it. Then, print your first name repeated 3 times.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to check the type of any variable and convert between common data types.
key_topics: The type() function for identifying data types
Explicit type conversion: int(), float(), str()
Common conversion scenarios and potential errors
Converting user input (which is always a string) to numbers

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables with an integer, a float, and a string. Use the type() function to check and print the type of each variable.
Use the input() function to ask the user for their birth year. Convert the input to an integer and calculate their age. Print a message stating their age.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to use comparison operators to evaluate expressions and store the Boolean results in variables.
key_topics: Boolean (bool) data type (True/False)
Comparison operators (==, !=, >, <, >=, <=)
Using comparisons to control program flow
Evaluating expressions with variables

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create two variables with numeric values. Write comparisons to check if they are equal, if one is greater than the other, and if one is less than or equal to the other. Print the result of each comparison.
Create a variable storing a correct password. Use input() to ask the user for a password. Compare the user's input to the correct password and print True if they match, False if they don't.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create a simple interactive program that takes user input and produces neatly formatted output.
key_topics: Getting user input with the input() function
Using f-strings for embedding variables in strings
Combining multiple data types in a single output
Creating a simple, interactive story or data summary

exercises.exercise_instructions: Ask the user for their name and favorite food. Use an f-string to print a message like: 'Hello [name]! I hear you love [food]!'
Ask the user for an adjective, a noun, and a verb. Use f-strings to insert these words into a pre-written story paragraph and print the complete story.
